title: First Kiss
body:
Dear First Kiss,
I still haven’t found you yet. Technically, you’d be my second kiss, but I choose not to count that one in eighth grade. It was short, and on a dare, and I didn’t really like her, not even as a friend, and it’s my life and my words, so. You’ll be my first kiss.
I hope you’re well, and not biding your time to meet me. I’m not waiting up to meet you. I hope you’ll come around, of course, but when I meet you, I want to be a person. I want us to be two people together, not two puzzle pieces that only feel complete in each other’s grasp.
Still, does it ever feel to you like it’s all a charade? Like romance is a big sham, or like there’s something about you that just makes everyone’s eyes slide right past you? I’ve been launching the fireworks of my affection into the night sky for years, and nobody has ever been there to catch the sparks. I begin to wonder if the glow of my displays is a color other people just can’t see.
Then, maybe probability has just been rude to me. I’m sure you’re out there. I haven’t done much kissing in my life, but I have done a lot of reading, and I’m skeptical of the magical qualities the fictional world ascribes to kisses- total bliss, clarity, and peace seem a bit much- but it still sounds pretty nice. I hope I won’t be too bad at it. You can be honest with me about it.
I hope you’ll wear glittery lip gloss, and I hope it sticks to me after you pull away. I hope it’ll sparkle in the morning sunlight in all the colors that it seems like no one else can see.

title: I'm at a party and the adults want to see my happy face
body:
walking through Greece
there I see the vines along the roads
with trash tucked under their leaves
a shy bottle cap not quite ripe
a torn foil flower
on the road itself
I see the space between the stones
and the spent cigarettes oriented there like compass needles
standing in Greece
there on the mountain, above the ocean, below my chlorine-thick hair,
we crowd around a balcony to watch the sun set
there's a town on the shore
and it looks like the bone-colored buildings and their rust-blush roofs have come from somewhere far away
to watch something on the shore
their dark windows intently facing the ocean
whatever they're looking for, I don't think they see it yet
crouched perfectly still in the dusty green hills, waiting, still waiting
swimming in Greece
dipping my head down so that my ears fill with water
sinking into the soft silence
throwing rocks further into the sea
and watching the glass lilies spring up at the impact
even in the calm ocean
floating so easily in the infinity of blue
I have so little peace
I try to forget about it all
I try to forget about my body and my brain
engaged in such quiet war against me
tuck it away, make it shy, hide it like a bottle cap under a leaf
everybody wants me to forget so I go up to the railing and look into the sun
the melted gold pink lemonade neon sign sun
here I am in Greece
listening to the eager buildings
and they tell me that
forgetting
is a lot easier
if you're doing it to make room for remembering something else

title: Back to You
body:
All roads will be leading back to you
what you know, what you have felt, lived
there is no state of the world
only a waterfall of humanity asserting itself into it
radio waves riding into space because, you see,
I am talking
and you should hear me
All roads will be leading back to you,
because this is your life
and you are living it in your head
and thus there is no escape from that town you call Bias,
or maybe Subjectivity
because to breach its borders
you must unbecome yourself
and this is an impossible task
you just stand
on the main street of your own life,
your gait wearing grooves in the pavement
and fling out your arms to assert yourself to the stream of passers-by.
Here you are. Only you.
I hope you like it.

title: three hours from america
body:
there the bees buzzed in big wobbly loops
and the graphite splintered over paper
and the metro doors crashed shut
and cigarette smoke billowed volcanic up from café tables
and tears broke flat onto pale concrete
and two people leaned closer together to hear each other talk
and cars just barely stopped as a glowing green petroglyph lit up
and the bleach-tired ends of a teenager's hair fluttered into the sink
and paper and coins passed haltingly from hand to hand
and a crane swiveled over the Notre Dame
and a creature of unknown identity picked up a knife and put it down again
and all the people walked over bridges like their paths were threads, like they were trying to sew together the banks of the Seine
and through it all the only ones still were the statues and the saints
their faces stained with incense and gold
gazing down at us
three hours from america we gazed up at them before swinging 'round to leave
hair floating behind us like incense smoke
as we flung open the ornate doors
and we walked out into a flood of sky

title: Blank Clock
body:
Wake up, wake up, wake up.
My soul lives
in a cramped apartment
and it doesn't know its way
around the city.
Every day my soul lies
in a creaky couch-bed.
Sometimes it feels
a great burst of pain,
but it's the kind of pain
that makes it still,
stitches its mouth shut
and all that is silent
becomes suffering.
Wake up, wake up, wake up,
if only to step onto the balcony,
narrow and too high
to hear a serenade from.
To let little sunbeams
pierce its chest.
Wake up, wake up, wake up!

title: The Kingdom
body:
The clouds have their thumbs
pressed against the spouts of
the hoses, righty tighty,
lefty loosey. I sit upon
a throne of stone with
my empty sleeve of crackers,
and the little stains of marker
covering my arms
are jewels rich enough
to rule the world.
Raindrops on the road,
on the roof, sound like
the deft keystrokes
of the universe. Have
you ever heard of the multiverse?
Well, you won't today,
because the clouds
are dousing the roofs and roads
and you can't see
three feet out of the window.
Everything is one thing,
one throne of stone,
one house it sits beside.

title: To Defy Gravity
body:
Is this all we are? Girls
in the seventh grade,
pushing their
math worksheets over
an air vent, and smiling
when they float?
This is what
time does-
make each moment into
life's greatest, most horrible
valley, plateau, peak.
We are tied tightly
to the present and it makes
for one hell of a ride.

title: The Truth
body:
All is lost in translation
but the vital
sentiment. Lattices of
intellect and thorn
pale before the one
essential truth, the
one starry thread that
weaves up into the
sky and down into
the sinking rocks
that bear first memory
of the utterance.
The rocks may melt
and all may be
lost but
the one essential
truth grows only
higher, ever wider,
all that matters
and all that
stays. I
love you.

title: The Pull
body:
Letting go is easy
when you know gravity
and the way it transports
from here to there.
Yes, it is
a force of death, too.
You should see me when
the edge of a cliff
approaches-
but what isn't a force of death?
Anything and everything
ends life if sent
towards it at even a moderate
velocity.
Gravity doesn't know how
to break bones and kill minds.
Your body doesn't know
how to be fragile.
Facts and forces
cannot know things.
Consequences are inevitable,
and both parties are trying their best.
When that is not enough
to save you, I hope
there may be a small comfort
in knowing
that this careless world
is only making an attempt
to hold you closer.

title: Paint & Paper
body:
I'm going to leave bowls of paint &
paper in the woods, offerings &
prayers to no one, to nothing &
to the future.
A future that is waiting for me &
that I am waiting for. Home &
hearth for my soul &
body on the other side of the tall &
tangled trees. Maybe I am wrong &
maybe there is nothing there.
But I can be a fool &
I can hope.

title: path up to Inglemoor
body:
daisies and pinecones
steep slopes and short braids
plantain chips and leaves
too green for this world
paths and mud
cobwebs in the sun
high school as a series
of colorful pillars
high school and archways
of empty speculation
slack tennis nets and a
glimpse of someone else's house
overgrown cattails
and bleachers that make
metallic music when you
kick and stomp
for an audience of zero
cutting your hands
to eat the blackberries
idle loops around the track
massive fields of quiet

title: Everything's Eternity
body:
The crows circle the courtyard in predictable flight
Their caws melt into the ambient chatter of the life lycee
Is this forever?
Painted concrete pillars mark
the paths we walk
over and over
Are we really just spinning our wheels?
Hell, man, I don't mind
I like the sound of my shoes
scraping against the ground
spinning in place
I like sitting and cursing out the rest of the world
my head against the brick wall
This place turns me around sometimes
it's not paradise,
yeah, sometimes I just can't jump to meet it
and then I wake up and I'm here again,
failure a rock in my shoe
man, though, I'm gonna tell you something
If this is forever
it's a better one because of you
and even if I'm just spinning my wheels
I hope we burn up
together.

title: Static/Sunrise
body:
My love is not a color human eyes can see, no, it's huddled at the far end of the electromagnetic spectrum, nowhere near the narrow band of sight that spangles our traded bouquets.
No, my love is the color of radio waves, those things so wide and slow, those things you have not any cones for. The things calmest, most powerful, reaching so far. I will never blind you, make you blink first and look away, foist my afterimage onto your retinas, no, I will not make you sick, I will not kill you as a gamma ray does.
You may not see me, but I still may move you, for your love is the color of a delicate dawn, a myriad of places visible that all somehow fit together.
Yes, your love is the color of the earliest morning, the earliest morning when you drag yourself out of bed and sit down in front of your rickety IKEA desk and get back to work on the machine all painted in pastel, trying to catch all that is spinning, dancing through the air around you that you yourself cannot sense.
Your love is the color of dawn because that is the sight before you as you, yes you, so poor with mechanics and yet so unflagging in your resolve, that is the color you see as you start fixing your homemade radio antenna.
That is the color you see when, finally, your love catches mine, and you lean in all robed in lavender and you hear my voice, starting to sing.

title: Mall Grief
body:
I wonder why
when someone dies
people say that
we've "lost" them.

Maybe that's what it's like
and when I die
it'll take me a while to notice
that I don't know any of the faces
around me
and then I'll grab onto a clothes rack
for comfort
and try not to cry even though
everyone walking by is so tall
and stand still
waiting
for my mother's voice
to come in
over the loudspeaker.

title: Narrowed Maps
body:
The road is empty in front of us
You're a bit spooky, all
black and green, lit only by
the glowing numbers on the dashboard
Sleep is nearly caught up with me
look, there it goes, by the stoplight
Motels flick past and then
back into oblivion
aren't we lucky to have
all this to ourselves right now?
The heater whirs, you smile,
the empty road flows past
